Reviews:
There isn't much else to say; Joker is one of the most absorbing, powerful films ever made. The cinematography is remarkable and the score is just perfectly potent and understated. This is not a thrill-a-minute movie designed to keep you entertained throughout. It is a heavy, all-consuming character study that invites you, with reluctance and fascination, into the mind of a severely disturbed outcast. I don't remember any movie leaving me feeling so emotionally disoriented as I left the cinema.

The performance by Joaquin Phoenix is something very special indeed. We spend nearly the full two hours just watching him close up and every second is exhilarating. Rarely, if ever, has a character been so utterly captivating, so desperate and so tragic. His physical acting, from writhing in anguish to dancing with warped delight, is utterly mesmerising. And not once did he ever lay it on too thick. To portray that level of pain and fury without indulging in excess morbidity or melodrama is quite an achievement.

Forget where this masterpiece fits into the world of DC comics and Batman movies; Joker is a stand-alone film that deservedly takes its place amongst the greats.

Reviews:
Joker is a contemporary example of a chef-d'oeuvre. It's a monumental piece of art. In essence, it's a masterpiece. Joker stars Joaquin Phoenix in a once in a lifetime portrayal of an iconic comic book villain. Barring any connection to the source material, Joker stands on its own as a film that will be upheld in the annals of the decade's best films.

Joker stars Joaquin Phoenix as Arthur Fleck, a mentally unstable man who is trying to find his place in a society that rejects him. Phoenix's portrayal of Arthur is perfection. Phoenix captures the essence of life with mental illness. In a career with so many masterful character portrayals, this is the one that viewers will cite as Phoenix's crown jewel. The emotion within the film supersedes great acting by taking a step into reality. Arthur Fleck is a character that is written so well and so real that it hurts. Where much of the media stigmatizes mental illness, the character of Arthur Fleck humanizes it.

The cinematography in this movie is incredible. 2019 has been a year of great camera work, and this film spearheads the year. There are many iconic scenes layered throughout the film that are phenomenally shot. As the movie progresses, the film grows exceptionally in terms of cinematography. At times it is hard to tell whether the movie was shot digitally or on film. Essentially, this movie bridges the gaps between new wave cinema and contemporary cinema in a graceful manner. The lighting used within the film is atmospheric and successfully matches Arthur's mood throughout the film. The cinematography is masterful.

This film is a Dramatic, Psychological Thriller with a great twist. The writing is insanely clever. The suspense is uncanny. The ending is satisfying and chilling. The supporting cast are great. They add weight to Arthur's emotion, successfully building him up and progressing his development. The soundtrack is iconic. The music enhances the overall experience as opposed to watering it down with noise. This film is damn near perfection. Todd Philips and Joaquin Phoenix created a modern masterpiece

Overall, Joker is a classic in the making. It challenges the stigma surrounding mental illness, presenting a narrative coupled with classism. This movie is important. In a zeitgeist where mental instability is a common issue, this film gives voice to the voiceless.

Reviews:
First of all, please do not compare Joaquin Phoenix's Joker with Heath Ledger's Joker. We are lucky to see two actors playing a very difficult character of Joker brilliantly in their own ways. They are both so good, they are both legends!

In terms of movie, Joker origin story is something very new and very much needed. It has always been emphasized in the DC world that Gotham was irredeemable, that the people were so corrupted that the city was beyond saving. But the reason behind it was never shown. The story has always been told from Batman's point of view. This storytelling is so brilliant, you really sympathize and understand why Joker is what it is. If you see Dark Knight just after this, Joker's love for chaos will make total sense.

It's good to see such a realistic cinema with characters having so much depth. The level of acting and movie making is legendary. Hats off!

Yes the hype is real. Do not miss this masterpiece.

Reviews:
Many of us over the years have been attached and thrilled with the "Clown Prince of Crime" as D.C. comic fans know as the one and only "Joker". And we've seen different takes and spins from Romero's camp, to Ledger's dark wild crazy turn, and the man the one and only Jack played the clown with vanity and brought a proper turn to a bad guy while having fun(Nicholson's "Joker" was like that of the late 70's early 80's "Joker" in D.C. comics) now enter Phoenix who's much different with a creepy origin story.

Set in the early 1980's Gotham city is gritty, raw and the social and political climate is in the gutter as just getting by is so tough. And just tip toeing and dancing his way thru the drama is Arthur Fleck(in a hell of a turn from Joaquin at least nominate him for a "Golden Globe" or "Oscar") a lonely and depressed mommies boy who's a skinny starving clown who just can't fit in he's a society misfit. It's really somewhat of a sad character study.

However hope is possible in the form of Fleck wanting to get away from being a clown for children as his real dream is to be a standup comedian as his smile and crazy lasting laugh is always present! As laughter is the cure for his pain! His hope of escape is to appear on a late night talk show hosted by Murray Franklin(Robert De Niro) where Arthur hopes to showcase his talents. Also the only other wild card pleasure he has in his life is dating a single mom named Sophie(Zazie Beetz) from his apartment building. And his sick mother Penny keeps Arthur hanging on with love and hope as that keeps him hanging on.

Only secrets and ghost of the past and painful memories only destroy the fragile mind of Arthur even more as a connection to millionaire Thomas Wayne is revealed and even more shattering is how this connection and more events will lead to "The Dark Knight". Great and excellent work from director Todd Phillips who despite making a stand alone dark character study still connects things up with others in the D.C. universe.

Many might see this picture as a dark tragedy I think it's a take and spin on how one is affected by life and then they take on a different role after years of being abused and mistreated in the world by it's people. Still this film is excellent because it's unique and finally glad a stand alone movie celebrates "The Joker"(the greatest comic book bad guy ever!) As Joaquin's performance was raw, gritty, and a lashing out of some payback to society. Wow enough said best D.C. comics character study ever made!

Reviews: This movie is as dark and morbid as they come. Don't expect this film to have anything to do with Batman or even the joker. They could've just made a film about a random person that struggles with mental health issues and it would've been a winner. Yes, it's a film about how the Joker came to be but for me, it was more than that. There's a much darker yet relatable story that it tells. It's almost a documentary about the very real illness that MANY of us face but are too scared to reveal until breaking point. The addition of the Joker, well, that's just a bonus. It's not often that a film can make you sympathise with the villain especially after some of the gruesome acts he does, yet, somehow by the end, you can't help but be on his side which actually makes you feel a little uncomfortable after the movies over. Brilliant film, incredible acting and certainly plays on your mind for a while after.

Reviews: Joaquin Phoenix as an actor has evolved and has created a name for himself. He has been on my radar since Signs and with every movie he has amazed me with his repertoire of talent. A movie that has been etched in my memory is Her. So with these expectations I watched Joker and I was not disappointed. This is the closest and the best origin story. I initially thought it would be an ordinary action flick pleasing everyone considering the director Todd Phillips who is known for The Hangover but I was wrong. This is a movie that every one will relate to, we all have a dark side, we all have felt or are lonely, and we do find society absurd though we conform. The way Joaquin breathes life into the character of Arthur a failed comedian and his slow transformation into Joker is definitely going to be taught at film schools....the finest piece of acting I have seen in ages. With Joker he has surpassed De Niro and DiCaprio in acting. Every other aspect of the movie is superb the haunting music, the dialogues the way it's shot and it is in every way relatable to what is happening today with the pandemic. Chaos. Watch it on repeat!!!!!

Reviews:
'Joker' is a huge breath of fresh air to the movie industry at the moment. The amount of mundane films that have been released in recent years has become somewhat tiresome. This film has set the bar for 2019's films.

'Joker' is a very educational film and is a real eye opener to the current state of affairs in terms of the oppression in society, more specifically, the lower class.

The film is paced brilliantly, is the perfect length, was never once boring and just outright engaging. So captivating and heart wrenching to watch that it really leaves you feeling stunned.

Cannot recommend this film enough

Reviews:
I Was not expecting this movie to be such a masterpiece at every single level. It is truly what a movie should be: transporting you in the psyche of someone that is not you and make you relate to this person in some strange way. I'm speechless by how incredible it was, how I was taken by surprise... We knew Phoenix to be a great actor for twisted vilain since Gladiator , but now it is going to be impossible to imagine the Joker without him playing it. There is such depth in his acting, such a raw interpretation of mental illness. I'm just baffled how he is able to carry the movie and this level of intensity from the first minute to the last one on -almost- a stand alone performance. Very impressive performance that make some A list actors look like amateur who can only play themselves. As an origin story for the joker, it brings so much depth to this DC character and thinking of the Joker now in previous Batman movie, make him become such an interesting vilain.

As a final note, I loved how they twisted the birth of Batman and kept the previous work done with Batman begins coherent but slightly different.

I thought before that DC was doing a poor job transposing their universe and character to the big screen (except for Batman Begins) but man, this movie changed my mind! Congrats to all the team who work on making this move a reality, and a standing ovation to Mr Phoenix for granting us of such an acting performance. Already a classic!

Reviews:
Joker is a masterpiece unlike any CBM(comic book movie) that has come before it.

It touches on topics that are extremely relevant in today's society such as mental health, modern-day crime and corruption, and moral bankruptcy through the journey of the main character, Arthur Fleck. He is a man with high hopes and dreams at the beginning of the film who struggles to make things work for himself due to his mental instability and inability to fit in. All the unfortunate events that take place transform Arthur into the infamous big bad of Gotham we all know, the Joker.

Joaquin Phoenix absolutely kills it in this movie. His poignant performance gave the movie what it needed in telling its dark and gritty story and is arguably the best Joker performance ever. The musical score was spot on and gave the movie the melancholic feel it sought to instill in its viewers. The film was aesthetically striking and a beauty to watch.

This was a film whose main character I heavily sympathized with and one that made me reflect on how we treat and regard those who are less fortunate. The film delivers a very powerful message about modern society.

Reviews: Watched it on day one, it's more than two months and I still have goosebumps. The movie isn't that original, isn't something that you haven't seen before, but it's original in its purpose and vision. Todd, Joaquin and the whole working team had made one of the most iconic movies of all time portraying a different and original version of the Joker we all know but he's a metal ill, twisted and a suffering man that tries to be loved, understood, he wants his tears to be dried and he wants to be one of us, but he can't, he knows he can't and for that he'll become something else, choosing a path that himself seems to not accept. Joker earns 10 stars from me, not only because it's a magnificent movie, but because it's easily recognisable and it will stuck in your minds as most of icons movies from the past has done with your mind. Last but not least: Oscar-worthy ? All-in.

Reviews: At first I was hesitant to watch this film, mainly because of DC's past movies like Suicide Squad, Batman V Superman, Justice League, etc. But this is a more realistic take on one of the most iconic super villains of all time. Joker is a cinematic masterpiece. The cinematography is spectacular and I never thought I would see another movie that looked as stunning as this. Joaquin Phoenix's performance in my opinion is better than Heath Ledgers. The movie is presented in a dream-like manor, moments where scenes are just fantasies in Arthur's head which makes it ambiguous and up for interpretation. The final 15 minutes is absolutely phenomenal and I left the movie theater with a smile, highly satisfied with what I saw. Film buffs would appreciate this movie more due to it's themes and Martin Scorsese-like-style. If you love Martin Scorseses movies like Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Goodfellas, then you will love this film. Don't listen to the mixed reviews, if you want to have a great 2 hrs and 2 mins, then go see this movie.

Reviews:
In a time when popcorn movies rule (and make no mistake, I enjoy those too) this is the exception. Every single aspect of this movie is astounding - acting (especially the acting - all hail Joaquin Phoenix), the music (I'm listening to it now - something I rarely do for movie soundtracks), the lighting, the sets - everything.

Watch it. Then watch it again. In the cinema both times.

But a gentle warning - it's not a superhero movie, it's not light, it's not especially fun (although there are some amusing moments), and it requires some concentration, but you will be captivated.

Reviews:
It was pretty clear from before the movie got released that despite being a central comic book villain, Joker would not be anywhere along the lines of any superhero/super villain film we've ever seen. Instead of having the clown of Gotham going on a mad rampage to burn down the city, we witness an origin story for Joker : a story of how a normal if not slightly delusional person on being bogged down by society can turn into an uncontrollable, cold-blooded madman that we all know of.

Joker's alter ego Arthur Fleck's struggles makes it immensely relatable and it is amazing to watch the character develop throughout the film. Joaquin Phoenix never fails, delivering a strong performance and proving that he is one of the best, most devoted method actors in the industry.

Joker rides on a simple plot fueled by a cast of extraordinary actors and a spine-chilling soundtrack which goes perfect with the protagonist's actions. With a couple of gory scenes, the movie can feel a bit heavy to handle. The movie, with beautiful cinematography ,successfully captures the essence Prince Clown of Gotham!

Reviews:
As a HUGE Nolan trilogy fan I went into this with low expectations. I mean, who could compare with Ledgers Joker portrayal, let alone compete with the great script and plot 'The Dark Knight' gave us?

I couldn't have been more wrong. This movie completely blew me away. Not only was this great entertainment, but I left the cinema genuinely moved. Joaquin Phoenix will win the Oscar this year- no doubts.

This is not the origin story of any joker you have seen before. This is a very different take, and dare I say more realistic dissection of a villain we have all loved and hated for over a decade. I would love to see a sequel but a) I don't know how it would work and b) would be so scared they tarnished this work of art.

If you haven't seen it yet, buy a ticket now and go. You will NOT be disappointed.

Reviews:
There is nothing more delightful than an orchastreted chaos!

Phoenix presents us a man who hasn't really existed for his whole life. The awfulness is a routine, as the happiness is completely absent, nonexperienced.

Thereby, we are forced to witness nothing but misery, due to an A. Fleck struggling to mitigate his own nature: the comedy within the artist.

When the one is finally able to give birth to himself, there are no more barriers to push him back. The society is no longer capable to disregard a man it no longer owns.

Put on a happy face...and enjoy a hilarious psycopath in his full glory.

That's all. That's life.

Reviews: I don't like violent films and I don't like comic books and comic book characters. That being said, I LOVED "Joker"--as a former New Yorker, I loved the "mood" and lighting of this film's "city," the "characters" you will only find in this crazy place, the lifestyle and intensity and madness that doesn't exist anywhere else on the planet and only really exists if you yourself are living somewhat on the edge. It's Bellevue and St. Vincent's and The Pyramid Club and every seedy street corner from "Law and Order SVU" rolled into one. Joaquin Phoenix is SO brilliantly uncomfortable you might check yourself in just to make sure you are still relatively the same person you were before you agreed to see this film.

Reviews: I'm literally impressed and extremely happy Joker will be the beginning of a revolution in the world of cinema and comic book movies ( i hope ). This movie is brilliant, thrilling, sad and a beautiful dark masterpiece. A spectacular character study with an unbelivebale and outstanding performance from Joaquin Phoenix, this is by far the best performance in last 10 years, the way he laughs, his body language, his eyes, his facial expressions are all out of this world, Joaquin conveys all types of emotions in a sensational way. The story is well paced and takes us step by step with arther and his fall from sanity to insanity each action and each detail matters and affects the coming events and makes us as audience understand to some degree the horrible actions that arther will do in the future. This movie accuses us the society and puts the blame on us for the way we treat ourselves and how we create within us monsters. The Joker that we get in the end is a moving representation of the corruption in our society and especially our media wich explains why there is a group of "critcs" that are demonizing The movie and ignoring the art in it and the big message it carries. Todd Philips you surprised me this is big jump in your career from comedy to such a perfected drama the shots, the close ups, the cinematography, the tone of the movie everything is really masterful and of course how can i forget Hildur guonadottir and her mesmerizing score that fits perfectly each scene and each transformations arther goes through, her soundtrack plays with our emotions and our nerves and makes us feel the darkness of this movie. This Film is nearly perfect, hard to watch, tough and makes you think about a lot of things. The only thing that may be bugging for some is the heavy inspiration from Scorsese's movies especially taxi driver and the king of comedy, i don't consider this a bad thing each filmmaker must be ispired from other works but it's a little but obvious here even so it's not a problem for me and because of all the other good things that impressed me and touched my soul and the questions that this work of art made me ask i give it a 10/10.
